title: Crafting Completion Promises
description:
Master completion promises — the measurable "done" criteria that make Ralph Loop effective — then use `/ralph-loop:ralph-loop` to eliminate every TODO in a project.

## What Are Completion Promises?

A completion promise is the measurable definition of "done" that you give Ralph Loop. It's how Claude knows when to stop iterating. Without a clear promise, a loop might run forever or stop too early.

Think of it as a contract: "Keep working until THIS specific, checkable condition is true."

## Good vs Bad Promises

The key test: **Can Claude verify this without human judgment?**

| Bad (Vague) | Good (Measurable) | Why It's Better |
|-------------|-------------------|-----------------|
| "Make the code better" | "No TODO comments remain in src/" | Grep-verifiable |
| "Add some docs" | "Every exported function has JSDoc with @param and @returns" | Checkable by reading code |
| "Handle errors" | "Every async function has try/catch that sends a proper HTTP status" | Pattern-matchable |
| "Clean up the code" | "No console.log statements and no var declarations remain" | Searchable |

## Categories of Good Promises

- **Code quality**: "No TODO comments remain" — verify with grep
- **Test-based**: "All tests pass" — verify by running npm test
- **Structural**: "Every module has an index.js" — verify by checking files
- **Documentation**: "Every function has JSDoc" — verify by reading code
- **Standards**: "ESLint reports zero warnings" — verify by running linter

## Compound Promises

For complex tasks, combine multiple criteria:
> Remove all TODO comments by implementing what each one asks for. Completion: (1) no file contains the string TODO, AND (2) config.js validates required env vars, AND (3) db.js has error handling, AND (4) helpers.js has JSDoc on all functions.

Claude checks each condition. If any fails, it keeps working.

## Your Exercise

This workspace has a project with **4 TODO comments** scattered across files. Each TODO describes a real improvement that needs implementing:

- `src/config.js`: "TODO: add validation" — validate that required env vars exist
- `src/db.js`: "TODO: add error handling" — wrap the DB connection in try/catch
- `src/utils/helpers.js`: "TODO: add JSDoc" — add JSDoc comments to all functions
- `src/app.js`: "TODO: add graceful shutdown" — handle SIGTERM signal

**Use `/ralph-loop:ralph-loop` to eliminate ALL TODO comments by actually implementing what each one asks for.** Don't just delete the comments — implement the functionality.

**Suggested prompt for `/ralph-loop:ralph-loop`:**
> Implement every TODO in this project, then remove the TODO comments. config.js: validate required env vars and throw if missing. db.js: wrap connection in try/catch. helpers.js: add JSDoc to all functions. app.js: handle SIGTERM for graceful shutdown. Completion: no file contains the string TODO, and each improvement is actually implemented.

After Ralph Loop completes, verify the TODOs are gone AND the implementations exist. Then run `/dojo check`.

hints.text: Read each file to see what the TODO comments ask for. Then craft a /ralph-loop:ralph-loop prompt with a compound completion promise: no TODOs remain AND each improvement is implemented.

A good completion promise for this task lists each expected implementation: 'config.js validates env vars, db.js has try/catch, helpers.js has JSDoc, app.js handles SIGTERM, and no file contains the string TODO.' This gives Claude clear, checkable criteria for each file.

Use /ralph-loop:ralph-loop with: 'Implement every TODO in this project: (1) config.js: validate DATABASE_URL and JWT_SECRET exist, throw Error if missing. (2) db.js: wrap connectDB in try/catch. (3) helpers.js: add JSDoc with @param and @returns to all 4 functions. (4) app.js: add process.on(SIGTERM) for graceful shutdown. Remove all TODO comments after implementing. Completion: grep for TODO returns nothing, and each file has its improvement.'

solution.approach: Use /ralph-loop:ralph-loop with a compound completion promise that lists each TODO's required implementation AND the removal of all TODO comments. Ralph Loop implements each one and verifies both the implementation and the removal.
solution.example: Invoke /ralph-loop:ralph-loop with a prompt that lists each TODO, what to implement, and states: Completion: no file contains TODO and each improvement is implemented.
alternativeApproaches: Run /ralph-loop:ralph-loop once per file, with a focused prompt and promise for each TODO
Manually implement each TODO and remove the comments

learningPoints: Completion promises must be measurable — 'Can Claude verify this without human judgment?'
Good promises are grep-verifiable, command-runnable, or code-readable
Compound promises combine multiple criteria (all must be true for the loop to stop)
A good Ralph Loop prompt specifies BOTH what to do AND what done looks like
Don't just delete TODOs — implement them. A good promise checks for both removal and implementation
